qas.question: What did a bunch of Germanic tribes celebrate?
How was the ship carrying a predominant deity moved around during the jubilee?
Why was the winter driven out?

answers.text: to make sure that fertility could return in spring

qas.question: What is Nerthus the goddess of?
How would the marriage of a man and woman on the ship serve as a fertility ritual?

context: Several Germanic tribes celebrated <a0_0>the returning of the daylight<a0_0/>. A predominant deity was during this jubilee driven around in a noisy procession on a ship <a1_0>on wheels<a1_0/>. The winter would be driven out, <a2_0>to make sure that fertility could return in spring<a2_0/>. A central figure was possibly the <a3_0>fertility<a3_0/> goddess Nerthus. Also there are some indications that the effigy of Nerthus or Freyr was placed on a ship with wheels and accompanied by a procession of people in animal disguise and men in women's clothes. Aboard the ship would the marriage of a man and woman <a4_0>be consummated<a4_0/> as a fertility ritual.
